table-wrap.anchoringText: Table 1 presents a general sequence of events that occurred, including cumulative injection and production achieved during the CO2 pilot. Discernible pressure responses at the production wells that could be attributed to injection at BU-1 were observed during planned shut-in periods. Pressure transient test results and inference from direct pressure measurements indicated obvious communication between injection and production wells.
table-wrap.label: Table 1
table-wrap.caption: General sequence of events and cumulative CO2 injection and oil production during the pilot CO2 flood

formatted-caption.caption-text: General sequence of events and cumulative CO2 injection and oil production during the pilot CO2 flood

table-wrap.anchoringText: A five-component Peng-Robinson equation of state (EOS) was used to generate pressure-volumetemperature (PVT) properties of the crude oil for CO2, C1, C2, C6, and C25. The mole fractions of these pseudo-components and their interaction parameters were refined to match reservoir fluid properties measured in the laboratory. The mole fractions of the pseudocomponents in the refined EOS are 0.01, 0.10, 0.16, 0.14, and 0.59 for CO2, C1, C2, C6, and C25, respectively. Table 2 presents the reservoir fluid properties at Mumford Hills.
table-wrap.label: Table 2
table-wrap.caption: Reservoir fluid properties at Mumford Hills (Frailey et al., 2012 )

formatted-caption.caption-text: Reservoir fluid properties at Mumford Hills (Frailey et al., 2012 )

table-wrap.anchoringText: Reservoir modeling results for both pilot scenarios predict significant incremental oil production compared to the Mumford Hills pilot because of the interrupted CO2 injection and short duration of the pilot. Model results predict an incremental oil recovery of about 48,000 stb (11% of OOIP) and 62,000 stb (14% of OOIP) for pilot scenario 1 and pilot scenario 2, respectively (Table 3), which are greater than the CO2 EOR of 2045 stb achieved in the pilot.
table-wrap.label: Table 3
table-wrap.caption: Projected EOR and CO2 utilization for the two pilot scenarios (modified from Frailey et al., 2012 ). ©2015 University of Illinois Board of Trustees. Used by permission of the Illinois State Geological Survey

formatted-caption.caption-text: Projected EOR and CO2 utilization for the two pilot scenarios (modified from Frailey et al., 2012 ). ©2015 University of Illinois Board of Trustees. Used by permission of the Illinois State Geological Survey

table-wrap.anchoringText: Field scenario 1 simulated four regular five-spot patterns consisting of 11 existing wells and three new wells (Fig. 8). Field scenario 2 simulated seven regular five-spot patterns consisting of 12 existing wells and nine new wells. CO2 was injected for 20 years in both scenarios. Model results predict an incremental oil recovery of about 106,000 stb (10% of OOIP) and 170,000 stb (12% of OOIP) for field scenario 1 and field scenario 2, respectively (Table 4).
table-wrap.label: Table 4
table-wrap.caption: Projected EOR and CO2 utilization for the two field development scenarios (modified from Frailey et al., 2012 ). Storage efficiency is relatively high due to additional storage in the pore space of the aquifer underlying the oil reservoir. ©2015 University of Illinois Board of Trustees. Used by permission of the Illinois State Geological Survey

formatted-caption.caption-text: Projected EOR and CO2 utilization for the two field development scenarios (modified from Frailey et al., 2012 ).
